verses.text: A good name is to be chosen over great riches; being highly esteemed is better than silver or gold.
verses.comment: Prioritizing integrity and reputation over material wealth echoes the spiritual teaching that inner virtue is of greater value than external riches, a theme common throughout both wisdom literature and the teachings of Christ (see Matt. 5:3).

verses.text: Rich and poor meet together; the LORD is the Maker of them all.
verses.comment: This verse teaches the radical equality of all people before God, laying a foundation for the Church as the unified family of believers regardless of status. See also Paul's teaching in Gal. 3:28.

verses.text: The prudent see danger and hide themselves, but the simple go on and suffer for it.
verses.comment: Wisdom involves discernment and caution, much as Christ exhorts his followers to be wise as serpents and innocent as doves (Matt. 10:16).

verses.text: Humility and fear of the LORD lead to riches, honor, and life.
verses.comment: The spiritual fruits of humility are echoed in the Beatitudes and suggest that true blessings flow from submission to God’s will.

verses.text: Thorns and snares are in the path of the crooked; whoever guards their soul stays far from them.
verses.comment: Here, the moral life is described as a guarded journey, reflecting the Church’s call to avoid the occasions of sin and seek holiness.

verses.text: Train up a child in the way he should go; even when he is old he will not depart from it.
verses.comment: This verse underscores the importance of lifelong spiritual formation, a principle carried on through the Church’s traditions of catechesis and family instruction.

verses.text: The rich rule over the poor, and the borrower is servant to the lender.
verses.comment: The reality of social structures warns against debt and highlights the need for systems of justice and mercy.

verses.text: Whoever sows injustice will reap calamity, and the rod of his wrath will fail.
verses.comment: The principle of sowing and reaping is a spiritual law affirming divine justice, later emphasized by Christ and the Apostles.

verses.text: The generous will themselves be blessed, for they share their bread with the poor.
verses.comment: Generosity is affirmed as a virtue bringing blessing, echoed by Jesus’ teaching on giving in Luke 6:38 and spiritual works of mercy.

verses.text: Drive out the scoffer, and strife will go out; quarreling and abuse will cease.
verses.comment: Unity and peace in the community are better maintained when divisiveness is addressed, with wisdom guiding discipline among the faithful.

verses.text: Whoever loves a pure heart and gracious speech will have the king as a friend.
verses.comment: Virtue and honesty attract favor, pointing toward the spiritual friendship with Christ the King for those living in truth.

verses.text: The eyes of the LORD protect knowledge, but he frustrates the words of the unfaithful.
verses.comment: God preserves true wisdom and opposes deceit, a theme that continues throughout salvation history.

verses.text: The lazy person says, 'There is a lion outside! I will be killed in the streets!'
verses.comment: Excuses for inaction are comically exaggerated, highlighting avoidance of responsibility. See also the warnings against sloth among the early saints.

verses.text: The mouth of an immoral woman is a deep pit; those under the LORD’s wrath will fall into it.
verses.comment: Moral purity is guarded by prudent living; falling into sin is described as divine judgment.

verses.text: Foolishness is bound up in the heart of a child, but discipline will drive it far from him.
verses.comment: The necessity of correction and guidance in youth is foundational to spiritual formation and mentorship in faith communities.

verses.text: Oppressing the poor to enrich oneself, or giving gifts to the rich, leads only to poverty.
verses.comment: Social justice is linked to personal prosperity, warning against exploitation and affirming God's concern for the poor.

verses.text: Incline your ear and hear the words of the wise, and apply your heart to my knowledge,
verses.comment: Listening to wisdom mirrors the posture of discipleship, as recommended by Christ and the apostles.

verses.text: for it will be pleasant if you keep them within you, let all of them be ready on your lips.
verses.comment: Internalizing wisdom equips believers for every good work, spiritually nourished by God’s Word.

verses.text: So that your trust may be in the LORD, I have made them known to you today, even to you.
verses.comment: Instruction is aimed at fostering faith and reliance on God—in both teaching and sacramental life.

verses.text: Have I not written for you thirty sayings of counsel and knowledge,
verses.comment: The book is structured for educational formation, reflecting traditional formulaic instruction.

verses.text: to show you what is true and right, that you may answer correctly to those who sent you?
verses.comment: Right judgment and truthful witness are key themes, later embodied in Christ’s role as the faithful and true witness (Rev. 3:14).

verses.text: Do not rob the poor, because he is poor, or crush the afflicted at the gate,
verses.comment: This command calls for justice toward the vulnerable, a central pillar of moral teaching.

verses.text: for the LORD will take up their case and will plunder the life of those who plunder them.
verses.comment: Divine justice and advocacy assure that the wronged are not forgotten, prefiguring Christ’s advocacy for the poor.

verses.text: Do not make friendship with someone easily angered, nor go with a hot-tempered man,
verses.comment: Association with anger-driven company is discouraged, suggesting the importance of peaceful community life.

verses.text: lest you learn his ways and entangle yourself in a snare.
verses.comment: The spiritual principle that bad company corrupts good morals (1 Cor. 15:33) is stated plainly.

verses.text: Do not be one of those who give pledges, who put up security for debts.
verses.comment: Warnings against hasty financial commitments safeguard stewardship and responsibility.

verses.text: If you have nothing with which to pay, why should your bed be taken from under you?
verses.comment: Financial imprudence can lead to loss of personal security; justice upholds protection for the vulnerable.

verses.text: Do not move the ancient boundary stone set by your ancestors.
verses.comment: Respect for tradition and communal boundaries reflects God’s order and the spiritual significance of receiving wisdom from the past.

verses.text: Do you see a man skilled in his work? He will stand before kings; he will not stand before obscure men.
verses.comment: Excellence in craftsmanship is rewarded with honor, echoing the Church’s tradition of honoring those who devote themselves to serving God and others.
